content: Food amount 0 (in validator 2) is illegal according to the constraints.
Desperately needs more tests, validators are not equivalent to test cases. I just had this clash in the wild and none of us got 100% despite passing the visible tests...

You state that the input is:
P the number of people on the island
F initial number of food
E the number of food obtained in a day
S the number of daily foods consumed by each person

BUT YOUR CODE SAYS:

F=int(input())
P=int(input())
E=int(input())
S=int(input())

Please FIX

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: There's nothing wrong with it.
in input statement you start with "P the number of people on the island", but in test you starts with number of food. It could be confusing.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: There is nothing to prevent my solving.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It has moderate difficulty and clear description

p is a single letter function name in ruby. Other variable names would be advised. I like the idea! Also, when I tried writing a solution, it was possible to pass all test cases but fail validator two (food output == food requirement) so I would like to see an additional test case for that.
There is an inconsistency in the order of the variables between the example and the code given at the start of the challenge, the variables are not in the same order.
Aside from the minor issues, I like the idea and context for the math problem.

the E input says "the number of food obtained in a day" is that per person... this is specified in "S" which makes it unclear.

Also the description lists inputs in PFES.. which makes the inputs 50,3,2,3 look like there are 50 people... until you look at the sample code and see that it reads F first. I think you should update the Input description to match that order.

I think your solution is off. 

Look at Test 3. 
Start with 100 units of food.
produce 1 per day, eat 5 per day (1 per person), net loss = 4 per day
100 / 4 = 25, so it should take 25 days to run out of food. Not 24 days.

I think if you put:
while food>=abs(E-(P*S)):
that should fix it

Also, the statement could be a little more clear, specifically:

"Print out how many days [[P]] persons can spend on this island under these conditions before running out of food"

The constraints are not consistent with some of the test cases / validators. Maybe you mean ≤ instead of < ?
In particular, the values of E and S in Validator 4 are way beyond the constraints.
Fixed it for you, if i was allowed.
Validator 2 is the one that should have equivalent visible test, because you can easily run into division by zero errors

Since author is not responsive, I've edited the constraint and moved Validator 2 to a new test/pair as Test 5. I've added a matching Validator with F = 0 and a simplified 'Forever' validator for Validator 2 (F != 0). I've also clarified in the statement that food produced each day can be eaten the same day.
